brief_description: This study will characterize the human maternal immune system and identify immune markers potentially associated with pre-term birth events.
brief_title: Characterization of the human maternal immune response 6 months or greater post delivery via cytometry Time-of-Flight(CyTOF).
condition_studied: Human maternal immune response 6 months or greater post delivery
description: Preterm births occur in 12 percent of pregnancies.   Preterm infants are at risk for long term health problems such as impaired hearing and vision, cerebral palsy and developmental delays. This study will characterize the human maternal preterm birth immune system using Cytometry-Time-of-Flight analysis of whole blood
hypothesis: Pregnancy-associated immune system differs between term and pre-term births
objectives: Characterize the human pregnancy-associated term and preterm birth maternal immune system and identify features predictive of spontaneous pre-term labor and birth
official_title: Characteriization of the human maternal preterm immune system via CyTOF analysis of whole blood sampling.

arm.description: A minimum of one preterm delivery 27_to_32 weeks
arm.name: Preterm Birth history

arm.description: A minimum of one full term delivery 37 weeks or greater
arm.name: Full Term Birth history

personnel.organization: March of Dimes Prematurity Research Center at Stanford University School of Medicine
personnel.site_name: March of Dimes Prematurity Research Center at Stanford University School of Medicine

pubmed.title: Implementing Mass Cytometry at the Bedside to Study the Immunological Basis of Human Diseases: Distinctive Immune Features in Patients with a History of Term or Preterm Birth.
